page.title: Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction: Professional Development Module
page.contents:
This professional development module is part of a suite of related resources. The suite includes the following resources:

  • Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction: Issue Brief
    This issue brief presents a broad overview of digital literacy as it relates to adult learners in English language acquisition programs. It is intended to serve as an introduction to the topic of digital literacy that teachers and administrators can use as a springboard to additional in-depth resources.

  • Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction: Companion Learning Resource

This digital magazine is a practical, comprehensive instructional resource written specifically for teachers. It provides numerous examples of instructional models, strategies, tools, and tasks for integrating digital literacy into English language instruction.

page.title: Digital Literacy
page.contents:
Used with permission from WebJunction, a program of OCLC,

http://www.webjunction.org/news/webjunction/the-internet-is-important-to-everyone.html.

Modern life in the United States requires technology skills:

  • Applying for a job

  • Communicating with children’s schools

  • Getting accurate health information

  • Communicating and collaborating using the Internet for higher education

  • Communicating and collaborating for employment

(Federal Communications Commission, 2010)

 

For adult English language learners, the digital divide is widened by:

  • Limits to technology hardware

  • Limited Internet access

  • Limited and varied English readability levels

  • Limited availability of information in learners’ native languages

  • Limited basic digital literacy skills

(National Institute for Literacy, 2008)

Listen to audio:

ELL_Intro_0010.mp3

Audio transcript

The demands of modern life in the United States require technology skills. Applying for a job, communicating with children’s schools, getting accurate health information, and communicating and collaborating using the Internet for higher education or employment all require the ability to use information and communication technologies.

The challenge to meet these demands is even greater when, in addition to the “digital divide,” there is a language barrier. For adult ELLsEnglish language learners, the digital divide is widened by limits to technology hardware, limited Internet access, limited and varied English readability levels, limited availability of information in learners’ native languages, and limited basic digital literacy skills.

Access to the Internet, and the digital literacy skills necessary for access, are important to individuals and to the nation. Whether for work, education, voting, or health, Internet access and digital literacy are important for individuals. Increased Internet capacity can spur economic growth nationally, while Internet use can cut national healthcare costs significantly.

page.title: Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our Lives
page.contents:
For instructors, curriculum developers, administrators, and state directors, this unit presents an overview of digital literacy in modern life, building from contexts and functions in participants’ own lives (e.g., online forms to prepare for medical visits, online bank transactions, e-mails from teachers).

The unit reviews digital literacy needs in adult English language learners’ lives and the need to integrate digital literacy into English language acquisition instruction, curriculum topics, themes, and units.

page.title: Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction
page.contents:
The module is designed for teachers and administrators interested in integrating digital literacy in their adult English Language Acquisition (previously referred to as ESL) classes and programs.

Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our lives

Unit 2: Information and Communication
Technologies for Language Learning

Unit 3: Digital Information Literacy

Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich
Environments

  • Each unit in the module looks at a different component of digital literacy.
  • Each unit includes activities that take you to the Internet to experience some aspect of digital literacy that is relevant to instruction for adult English language learners.
  • Each unit is independent. The units can be completed in any order. However, Unit 4 is targeted to teachers who are already using technology with their students and want to deepen and expand that use.
  • Sections within each unit are addressed specifically to administrators.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Intro_0020.mp3

Audio transcript


Welcome! This module is designed for teachers and curriculum developers as well as administrators and state directors who are interested in increasing digital literacy in their adult English language acquisition classes and programs. It includes four units:

Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our Lives
Unit 2: Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning
Unit 3: Digital Information Literacy
Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich Environments

Each unit in the module looks at a different component of digital literacy.

Each unit includes information as well as unit activities that take you to the Internet to experience some aspect of digital literacy that is relevant to instruction for adult English language learners.

Each unit is independent, and the units can be completed in any order. However, Unit 4 is more for teachers who are already using technology with their students and want to deepen and expand that use. Sections within each unit are addressed specifically to administrators.

page.title: Unit 2: Information and Communication Technologies
page.contents:
This unit is an overview on using information and communication technologies to communicate in everyday life and in English language acquisition classes.

The focus is on instructional strategies that leverage technology to extend learning beyond the classroom as well as to provide independent learning opportunities.

Information and communication technologies provide the opportunity for English language learners to interact with people outside of English class, read and write for authentic purposes, and read and create multimodal texts.

page.title: Peer or Small Group Study
page.contents:
How to Use this Module

Find a peer or small group to explore the issues in this module in depth. The module readings, resources, and tasks can be completed between meetings and can be used for the basis of intentional exploration of the issues addressed in the module.

A third way to use the units in this module is to form one’s own small group of peers. The pages of the module can be read together and the Internet “field trips” done together or done in between meetings. Either way, the material can serve as a springboard for intentional exploration of and experimentation with new ideas and practices. Reciprocal peer observation, where peers doing collaborative professional learning take turns observing each other’s teaching, can also support professional learning in conjunction with the units in this model.

Now, it is time to get started! It is best to do Unit 1 first. After completing Unit 1, select any of the other units. Happy learning!

page.title: Unit 3: Digital Information Literacy
page.contents:
This unit is an overview of digital information literacy. The unit includes using search techniques for things that are important to English language learners, such as how to navigate the complex website of a child’s school; how to compare information from different sources on a medication being prescribed, in a medical unit; and how to compare loan interest rates and terms, in a financial unit.  

The unit includes ways to teach effective search strategies and ways to teach learners how to be critical consumers of online information.

page.title: Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich Environments
page.contents:
This unit is an overview of solving problems in technology-rich environments. The unit uses examples from a variety of topics taught in adult English language acquisition classrooms to illustrate strategies for teaching problem solving.  Problem-solving strategies are extended to technology-rich environments, expanding students’ digital literacy skills.  

This unit is designed for teachers who are already integrating technology into their classrooms and want to expand that use.

page.title: Individual Self-Study
page.contents:
How to Use this Module

This self-paced module allows individuals to complete any or all units at their own pace. Each unit should take approximately two and a half to three hours to complete, including readings and activities.  However, each unit offers many opportunities for deeper learning and access to many resources which would take longer to complete if you choose to access these additional opportunities.

You can complete the module over time, stopping as often as you’d like.  After a period of inactivity, you will be logged out of the module and will need to login to continue the activities. Use the checkboxes on the module home page to keep track of the activities you’ve completed. The unit activities are presented in a suggested order of completion.  However, you can complete the unit activities in any order and also return to previously completed activities to review material. 

The professional development modules in this series can be used in a number of different ways. They can be used for self study by individuals working at their own pace, by a group of educators working together in a professional learning community, as the focus of a study circle or by a small group of peers. When working individually, each unit takes 2–3 hours to complete. Each unit involves an examination of one’s own digital literacy as a springboard for thinking about digital literacy in students’ lives. Each unit includes opportunities to go deeper as well as technology tips for learning how to manage in a technology environment. Each unit also includes multiple “field trips” to a variety of Internet sites.

page.title: Professional Learning Communities/Study Circles
page.contents:
How to Use this Module

A professional learning community, or PLC, is a group of educators that meets regularly, shares expertise, and works collaboratively to improve teaching skills and the academic performance of learners. Shirley Hord (1997), an expert on school leadership, defines professional learning communities this way: “The three words explain the concept: Professionals coming together in a group—a community—to learn.” One technique for your PLC is to conduct Study Circles. Anyone can initiate a study circle, but it is important to collaborate with an instructional leader to support this activity.

The module readings, resources, and tasks can be completed between meetings and can be used as the basis for intentional exploration of the issues addressed in the module.

This module can also be used as the material for a professional learning community or study circle. Professionals coming together for professional learning can be a powerful force for professional growth that improves student learning. Each unit in the module contains readings and Internet site visits that can be done between meetings. These readings form the basis for professional discussion and intentional exploration of the issues involved with integrating digital literacy into English language instruction.
